items.title: Document dependency on `python-dev`/`python3-dev`
items.body:
Using the `pip install glances` install method (on Mint 19.3, based on Ubuntu 18.04), the install failed with:

```
    psutil/_psutil_common.c:9:10: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
     #include <Python.h>
              ^~~~~~~~~~
    compilation terminated.
    error: command 'x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

Somewhere there should be a mention that glances is dependent on the `python-dev` package and/or `python3-dev` (I installed both before retrying the install).

items.title: Regex fix for hide conf key
items.body:
EDIT: Title is incorrect, it's not just for network but obviously for all plugin objects. That's just where I started debugging.
#### Description

Regex in the .conf never matches the hide parameter. 
Probably this passed testing on Linux as most mounts and files are lowercase, but this breaks a lot on Windows. The simplest example is for [fs] where hide=C:\ will never match, because this is made .lower() and on top of that, the not all(j is None...) is asking if the value matched all regexes that were supplied in the conf, when it only needs to match one of the regexes to be hidden (if my guess at the designer's intention is accuarate).

Recommended fix: (glances/plugins/glances_plugin.py)
`def is_hide(self, value, header=""):` function should look like this: 
`return any(j for j in [re.match(i, value) for i in self.get_conf_value('hide', header=header)])` 
instead of this:
`return not all(j is None for j in [re.match(i, value.lower()) for i in self.get_conf_value('hide', header=header)])`

#### Versions

* Glances & psutil (glances -V): Glances v3.1.4.1 with PsUtil v5.7.0
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): Windows 10

items.title: class AmpsList method _build_amps_list() Windows fail (glances/amps_list.py)
items.body:
When comparing the .conf regex for an AMP, the regex is almost certain to fail on Windows OS.

The problem lies with the "for c in p['cmdline']:" line within the method. Some processes have a value of 'None' for the key 'cmdline' where a list is expected, meaning the except is tripped (NoneType object is not iterable) and the for loop exits; the regex search has failed. 
In my case it was failing when doing the regex comparison against Desktop Window Manager (dwm.exe) in Windows 10.

Recommend a check of the key p['cmdline'] prior to looping through it (prior to the "for c in p['cmdline']" loop) as that fixed it for me, just a simple:
`if p['cmdline'] is None:
    continue`

items.title: Bug: [fs] plugin needs to reflect user disk space usage
items.body:
#### Bug description

[python-pystache](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/python-pystache/) is required for the mustache templating.
When I start glances with 2 mins refresh time, I want to execute an action that alerts me when my disk usage is above 90%.
What I see is if I use the "%" character, everything breaks with error **AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get_stats_display'**, so I need to use two "%%" characters to escape it.
The second issue is I want to get an alert email, and I am getting two alert emails related to disk usage at the same time.
When I see [`actions.py`](https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/develop/glances/actions.py), I observe:

>  Goal: avoid to execute the same command twice

Technically, the action is being executed twice, since I am getting two identical alert emails at the same time.
When I execute the echo command directly from the command line outside of glances and its conf, I get one email.
So there is definitely an issue within `glances actions`.

#### Versions

* Glances & psutil (glances -V): Glances v3.1.4.1 with PsUtil v5.7.0
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): LSB Version: 1.4, Arch Linux rolling

Packages: [glances](https://www.archlinux.org/packages/community/any/glances/) & [python-pystache](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/python-pystache/)

#### Conf
```ini
[fs]
disable=False
# Define the list of hidden file system (comma-separated regexp)
hide=/boot.*,/snap.*
# Define filesystem space thresholds in %
# Default values if not defined: 50/70/90
# It is also possible to define per mount point value
# Example: /_careful=40
careful=50
warning=70
critical=90
critical_action_repeat=echo -e "Used filesystem disk space for {{device_name}} is at {{percent}}%%.\nPlease cleanup the filesystem to clear the alert.\nScaleway server: $(uname -rn)" | mail -s "CRITICAL: disk usage above 90%%" -r postmaster@example.com hlfh@example.com
# Allow additional file system types (comma-separated FS type)
#allow=zfs
```

#### systemd `/etc/systemd/system/glances.service`
```systemd
[Unit]
Description=Glances Server

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/glances --quiet -t 120

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```

#### Logs
What I am getting in debug mode:
```log
2020-05-12 15:58:35,928 -- INFO -- Start Glances 3.1.4.1
2020-05-12 15:58:35,928 -- INFO -- CPython 3.8.2 and psutil 5.7.0 detected
```

items.title: Add lighttpd reverse proxy config to the wiki
items.body:
How about adding the reverse proxy config for lighttpd.  It took me some time to figure it out and thought others might want it too.

```
$HTTP["url"] =~ "^/glances" {
    url.rewrite-once = ( "^(/glances)$" => "$1/" )
    proxy.server = ("" => (( "host" => "localhost", "port" => 61208 )))
    proxy.header = ( "map-urlpath" => ( "/glances" => "" ) )
}
```

items.title: Undefined name 'i' in plugins/glances_gpu.py
items.body:
Before filling this issue, please read the manual (https://glances.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) and search if the bug do not already exists in the database (https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/issues).

#### Description

For a bug: Describe the bug and list the steps you used when the issue occurred.

[flake8](http://flake8.pycqa.org) testing of https://github.com/nicolargo/glances on Python 3.8.1

$ __flake8 . --count --select=E9,F63,F7,F82 --show-source --statistics__
```
./glances/plugins/glances_gpu.py:206:43: F821 undefined name 'i'
                    value = to_fahrenheit(i['value'])
                                          ^
1     F821 undefined name 'i'
1
```
https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/develop/glances/plugins/glances_gpu.py#L206

https://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/error-codes.html

On the flake8 test selection, this PR does _not_ focus on "_style violations_" (the majority of flake8 error codes that [__psf/black__](https://github.com/psf/black) can autocorrect).  Instead these tests are focus on runtime safety and correctness:
* E9 tests are about Python syntax errors usually raised because flake8 can not build an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST).  Often these issues are a sign of unused code or code that has not been ported to Python 3.  These would be compile-time errors in a compiled language but in a dynamic language like Python they result in the script halting/crashing on the user.
* F63 tests are usually about the confusion between identity and equality in Python.  Use ==/!= to compare str, bytes, and int literals is the classic case.  These are areas where __a == b__ is True but __a is b__ is False (or vice versa).  Python >= 3.8 will raise SyntaxWarnings on these instances.
* F7 tests logic errors and syntax errors in type hints
* F82 tests are almost always _undefined names_ which are usually a sign of a typo, missing imports, or code that has not been ported to Python 3.  These also would be compile-time errors in a compiled language but in Python a __NameError__ is raised which will halt/crash the script on the user.


For an enhancement or new feature: Describe your needs.

#### Versions

* Glances & psutil (glances -V):
* Operating System (lsb_release -a):

#### Logs

You can also pastebin the Glances logs file (https://glances.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#logging)

items.title: Fix gpu plugin to handle multiple gpus with different reporting capabilities
items.body:
#### Description

Bug: Computers with multiple Nvidia GPUs may have different level of compute capability and ability to report GPU % and GPU mem % utilization rates. For example GTX 780 with compute capability 3.5 is not able to provide those measurements while RTX 2080 Ti can provide measurements. 


Fix is provided as follows for python 3 against Glances version 3.1.5:
```diff
$ git diff
diff --git a/glances/plugins/glances_gpu.py b/glances/plugins/glances_gpu.py
index 9fd1c292..9f2510fc 100644
--- a/glances/plugins/glances_gpu.py
+++ b/glances/plugins/glances_gpu.py
@@ -226,11 +226,11 @@ class Plugin(GlancesPlugin):
                 id_msg = '{}'.format(gpu_stats['gpu_id'])
                 try:
                     proc_msg = '{:>3.0f}%'.format(gpu_stats['proc'])
-                except ValueError:
+                except (ValueError, TypeError):
                     proc_msg = '{:>4}'.format('N/A')
                 try:
                     mem_msg = '{:>3.0f}%'.format(gpu_stats['mem'])
-                except ValueError:
+                except (ValueError, TypeError):
                     mem_msg = '{:>4}'.format('N/A')
                 msg = '{}: {} mem: {}'.format(id_msg,
                                               proc_msg,
```

items.title: Glances 3.1.3: when no network interface with Public address -- Error while initializing the ip plugin ('NoneType' object has no attribute 'split')
items.body:
Hi glances developers,

Under **CentOS-8.1 (4.18.0-147.5.1.el8_1.x86_64)** found a bug in the stable version of **Glances v3.1.3 with psutil v5.7.0**.

The point of the bug: if there is _no network interface with a public IP address_ in the system, i.e. no access to the Internet (any other network interfaces may be present), running glances will cause an error:
`2020-03-02 15:23:38,010 -- INFO -- Start GlancesStandalone mode`
`2020-03-02 15:23:40,759 -- CRITICAL -- Error while initializing the ip plugin ('NoneType' object has no attribute 'split')`
`2020-03-02 15:23:40,770 -- ERROR -- Traceback (most recent call last):`
`  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glances/stats.py", line 120, in _load_plugin
    self._plugins[name] = plugin.Plugin(args=args, config=config)`
`  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glances/plugins/glances_ip.py", line 65, in __init__
    self.public_address = PublicIpAddress().get()`
`  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glances/plugins/glances_ip.py", line 178, in get
    return ', '.join(set([x.strip() for x in ip.split(',')]))`
`AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'split'`

The bug has 100% repeatability: as soon as the system has a network interface with a public IP address, i.e. Internet access, glances is launched normally without the error above.

I installed the stable version of glances from the Internet with the command `curl -L https://bit.ly/glances | /bin/bash`.

Very thanks for the support.

items.title: Feature request: Include hostname in all (e.g. kafka) exports
items.body:
#### Description

When running Glances in standalone mode for the sake of exporting stats/metrics to a centralized collector (e.g. Kafka, elasticsearch), I've noticed that each stat "dimension" (e.g. system, uptime, gpu, cpu, docker, mem, etc.) is exported as its own document/message.  This is a great design, however there is no "nice" way to correlate all of these documents/messages to the host from which they came.

For example, I've setup a kafka exporter on a host, and when I subscribe to a topic and print out the received message's key/value, I see things like this:

```json
key is: load. value is: {u'min15': 0.08, u'load_careful': 0.7, u'load_disable': u'False', u'history_size': 28800.0, u'load_warning': 1.0, u'load_critical': 5.0, u'cpucore': 1, u'min1': 0.04, u'min5': 0.06}
```

```json
key is: uptime. value is: {u'seconds': 58527, u'history_size': 28800.0}
```

```json
key is: system. value is: {u'os_name': u'Linux', u'os_version': u'4.15.0-42-generic', u'linux_distro': u'Ubuntu 18.04', u'hostname': u'knemol-ar-glances-bionic-benlocal', u'platform': u'64bit', u'history_size': 28800.0, u'hr_name': u'Ubuntu 18.04 64bit'}
```

The `system` stat actually does include the hostname of the host, but none of the other ones do.  If it were just a single system reporting, this wouldn't be an issue, but I plan to onboard many more hosts.  I'd rather avoid creating a topic/index per host.  If the system's hostname were included in each stat export, it would make it easier to aggregate metrics in, say, Kibana or Grafana.


#### Versions

* Glances & psutil (glances -V):

items.title: Kafka key name needs to be bytes
items.body:
https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/3e5ec443cea6edfd705622b4c90da2783ff8bc35/glances/exports/glances_kafka.py#L88

when running glances as follows:

```shell
glances -d -t 5 -C C:\glances\glances.conf --disable-plugin ip --export kafka
```

I would see errors showing up on the local logs like this:

```text
2020-02-05 08:19:14,144 -- ERROR -- Cannot export system stats to Kafka ()
```

I played around with some local python code and kafka-python, and discovered that the `key` argument of the `KafkaProducer.send()` method must be of type byte.

I hacked the glances source locally and changed this:

```python
try:
            self.client.send(self.topic,
                             key=name),
                             value=data)
```

to this:

```python
try:
            self.client.send(self.topic,
                             key=bytes(name, 'utf-8'),
                             value=data)
```

and now my consumer can see the messages flowing.

items.title: log file under public/shared tmp/ folders must not have deterministic name
items.body:
#### Description

I had run into elderly https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/issues/474 on an elderly glances (2.1.1) on debian, which brought my attention to this issue.
To the date it seems (according to docs in https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/16a9ce3ad1b0faf91bf791397743e0eac4b38389/docs/config.rst#logging) that 

    By default, the glances-USERNAME.log file is under the temporary directory

which could be a vector for attacks/information leaking etc etc, because temporary directory usually allows modifications to any user, so an attacker could (pre)create a log file (or symlink to e.g. /etc/passwd targetting a root user) causing glances to write into an "existing" file.  So it could potentially have many security implications.

That is why all tools avoid deterministic file names in temporary directories, so if you look under e.g. /var/tmp you would see that systemd always adds some randomly looking uuid, etc.

Anyways, we are talking about log files, so they ideally should not be in /tmp anyways, but somewhere where logs are expected to be found. E.g. XDG could be consulted (there is appdirs python module to assist with that): https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25897836/where-should-i-write-a-user-specific-log-file-to-and-be-xdg-base-directory-comp ; and for root they could even go under /var/log/glances.log or alike.

items.title: Autostart as 'glances -s'  - possible security issue?
items.body:
I installed glances on raspberry pi buster via apt-get.
Works great. Love the program.

But then I found out that glances starts by default in -s mode , which is not what I expected or asked for during install.
Furthermore, it was accepting client connections with no password request, which exposes the data to anyone.

Suggestions:
1. Default install DOES NOT install server mode, or at least asks the user for the mode they want.
2. Default passwordless access blocked and either force the user to set a password, or generate a random password that the user can change later.

It was easy enough to disable it with: systemctl disable glances.service , but this is after I accidentally found the open port while troubleshooting an unrelated issue on the box.

Thanks

items.title: ubuntu: glances package does not install a systemd service
items.body:
While https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/issues/1560 documented creation of a service this should not be a manual step taken by someone installing glance.

Like other packages like nginx, apache,... they should also include the service. In that particular case the services should not be installed by default because is an optional feature, the tool being usable even without a service.

**update**: description incorrect, see https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/issues/1569#issuecomment-565742311

items.title: install / Systemd Debian
items.body:
Hi, i tried to follow this :

https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/wiki/Start-Glances-through-Systemd

I want to Start a Glances client exporting stats to an InfluxDB server.  When i run **sudo systemctl start glances.service**, and then **sudo systemctl status glances.service**, i get :


glances.service - Glances
Loaded: loaded (/etc/systemd/system/glances.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
Active: activating ( auto-restart)(Result: exit-code) since Sat 2019-11-16 15:27:45 CET; 7s ago
Process: 1215 ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/glances -- quiet --export-influxdb (code=exited, status=2)
Main PID: 1215 (code=exited, status=2)

And glances doesn't appear in the task manager.

I tried to run the command **/usr/local/bin/glances --quiet --export-influxdb**, the command doesn't work. With the command : 

**/usr/local/bin/glances --export influxdb &** 

It does work. Trying to replace the command in the service file with this one won't work.

items.title: GPU stats not showing on mobile web view
items.body: I have the latest version of glances installed and running it in web server mode `glances -w`. If I access the web server from a desktop computer, the GPU stats are visible, but if I access it from a mobile (vertical or horizontal view) they are not displayed. Same is true if I access the web server from a pad in vertical view (stats are not displayed), however in a horizontal view they are.

items.title: Display load as percentage when Irix mode is disable
items.body:
For the moment (Glances 3.1.3), the Irix mode is limited to the processes CPU percent.

When it is enable (using the '0' key), it display CPU%/Core for all the processes.

The goal of this issue is also to enable the Irix mode support for the load.

items.title: [WebUI] Add a new TCP connections status plugin
items.body:
The TCP connections status plugin as been added in the DEVELOP branch (see https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/issues/1526).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/776747/66426705-b6e0af80-ea12-11e9-8ae1-0f393b0ea400.png)

Only the Curses interface is available.

The goal of this ER is to implement the WebUI for this new plugin.

items.title: IP plugin still exporting data when disabled
items.body:
#### Description
When disabling the IP plugin an empty string is still exported (using influxdb). The IP portion of curses interface is disabled however.

Disabling the plugin through conf file with
```
[ip]
disable=true
```

Running with
`glances -d --export influxdb`

Observed measurement data in influxdb
```
> SELECT * FROM ip ORDER BY time DESC LIMIT 5
name: ip
time       history_size host                    ip_disable
----       ------------ ----                    ----------
1570164122 28800        vm15-dev-v2 true
1570164119 28800        vm15-dev-v2 true
1570164116 28800        vm15-dev-v2 true
1570164090 28800        vm15-dev-v2 true
1570164087 28800        vm15-dev-v2 true
```

If enabling ip plugin again (as well as re-appearing in upper right of curses interface):
```
> SELECT * FROM ip ORDER BY time DESC LIMIt 5
name: ip
time       address         gateway       history_size host                    ip_disable mask          mask_cidr public_address
----       -------         -------       ------------ ----                    ---------- ----          --------- --------------
1570164455 157.230.132.137 157.230.128.1 28800        vm15-dev-v2 false      255.255.240.0 20        2604:a880:2:d0::52b7:1
1570164452 157.230.132.137 157.230.128.1 28800        vm15-dev-v2 false      255.255.240.0 20        2604:a880:2:d0::52b7:1
1570164449 157.230.132.137 157.230.128.1 28800        vm15-dev-v2 false      255.255.240.0 20        2604:a880:2:d0::52b7:1
1570164446 157.230.132.137 157.230.128.1 28800        vm15-dev-v2 false      255.255.240.0 20        2604:a880:2:d0::52b7:1
1570164443 157.230.132.137 157.230.128.1 28800        vm15-dev-v2 false      255.255.240.0 20        2604:a880:2:d0::52b7:1
```

#### Versions
Glances v3.1.2 with psutil v5.6.3
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS
Release:	18.04
Codename:	bionic

#### Logs
You can see the ip plugin being listed as disabled in log. But still exporting data to influxdb regardless.
https://pastebin.com/F1D2aatA

```
startup
...
2019-10-04 04:23:17,296 -- DEBUG -- ip disabled by the configuration file
...
exporting
...
2019-10-04 04:23:17,707 -- DEBUG -- Export ip stats to InfluxDB
2019-10-04 04:23:17,716 -- DEBUG -- http://HOSTNAME:PORT "POST /write?db=DB HTTP/1.1" 204 0
```

items.title: Running glances starts Sysinfo 0.7 again and again
items.body:
#### Description

Whenever I run glances, the Sysinfo 0.7 programm (sourceforge.net/projects/gsysinfo) gets started before the glances output even appears. When I close that program it immediately gets restarted, again and again and again.

#### Versions

* Glances & psutil (glances -V):  v3.1.2, v5.6.3
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): Ubuntu 18.04.3 
* Python: Anaconda (conda version 4.7.12)
* Installed with pip install

items.title: xmlrpc service is unprotected and enabled by default!
items.body:
as i recently found, glances by default enable a systemd service which starts a xmlrpc server bound to 0.0.0.0.
everyone is able to call all APIs without a password, which is extremely dangerous!
please fix it

items.title: [ports] ICMP does not work
items.body:
#### Description

I use Glances in a Docker container. I'd like to use the `[ports]` section to ping (using ICMP) devices on my local network. If I use a specific port with `port_x_port` (like `Router` on my pic), then everything is fine. If I omit the port number to use ICMP, then `Scanning` can be read, nothing else. Note that there is `Scanning` with `DefaultGateway` as well. 
![](https://i.ibb.co/ngzPTVW/image.png)

#### Versions

* Glances v3.1.1b0 with psutil v5.4.8
* Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

#### Logs

```
2019-09-06 19:51:03,413 -- INFO -- Start Glances 3.1.1b0
2019-09-06 19:51:03,414 -- INFO -- CPython 2.7.15rc1 and psutil 5.4.8 detected
2019-09-06 19:51:03,418 -- INFO -- Search glances.conf file in /glances/conf/glances.conf
2019-09-06 19:51:03,422 -- INFO -- Read configuration file '/glances/conf/glances.conf'
```

tests are running in empty network namespace, probably it triggers the following issues:
```shell-session
running test

Error while initializing the ip plugin ('NoneType' object has no attribute 'split')
```

items.title: Performance issue with large folder
items.body:
#### Description

I noticed a large usage of CPU and memory when I try to monitor some folders size.

The folder I have tried : 
- 65000 sub-directories
- 73000 files

_glances.conf:_
```
[folders]
folder_1_path=/folders_monitored/home
folder_1_careful=60000
folder_1_warning=70000
folder_1_critical=80000
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3708059/58938583-72e45200-8775-11e9-8f1b-01c38fa24e1d.png)
_The same line without folder monitoring is `30% CPU` and `40M MEM`_

#### Hints

I suspect [this recursive fonction](https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/develop/glances/folder_list.py#L140) to hurt the performances.

[This stack overflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/1392549/2666094) argue about the performances, but if you want to keep the python 2.7 compatibility, solutions will be limited.

If nothing is possible to improve the performances of this fonction I suggest to update this metric less often.

#### Versions

* Glances & psutil (glances -V): Glances v3.1.0_beta with psutil v5.4.3
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): Docker version on Alpine Linux (the host)

items.title: Highly Recommend to add pynvml in requirements.txt
items.body:
I installed glances but couldn't see the gpu information, and just now I found the reason: I didn't install pynvml. After I installed that, everything goes right. 
So I highly recommend that pynvml should be added in requirements.txt
